17.text:
but discovered instead cadavers
strewn about our morning papers,

21.text:
waterlogged facsimiles
of our sisters, spouses, small children.

26.text:
Say to your baby of this year
when she asks, as she certainly should,

30.text: tell her it was too late coming.

31.text:
Admit even in the year we leased freedom,
we didn't own it outright.

36.text:
There were still laws
for every way we used our privates

39.text: while they pawed at the soft folds of us,

41.text: grabbed with no concern for consent,

44.text:
no laws made for the men
that enforced them.

49.text: to wait, to cower and cover,

55.text: We were told to be silent.

57.text: But speak to your girls of this wartime,

59.text: a year preceded by a score of the same,

62.text: so as in two decades before,

68.text: evacuated the crime scene of the club,

71.text:
laid our bodies on the concrete
against the outlines of our fallen,

81.text: In the same year, we were ready.

84.text:
The year we lost our inhibition
and moved with courageous abandon

87.text: was also the year we stared down barrels,

89.text:
sang of cranes in skies,
ducked and parried,

92.text:
caught gold in hijab,
collected death threats,

96.text:
said, "We're 35 now, time we settled down
and found a running mate,"

99.text:
made road maps for infant joy,
shamed nothing but fear,

102.text: called ourselves fat and meant, of course,

114.text:
Remind them that the year has passed
to be docile or small.

118.text:
Some of us said for the first time
that we were women,

120.text: took this oath of solidarity seriously.

123.text:
Some of us bore children
and some of us did not,

125.text:
and none of us questioned
whether that made us real

129.text: When she asks you of this year,

131.text:
your daughter, whether your offspring
or heir to your triumph,

134.text:
from her comforted side of history
teetering towards woman,

137.text: she will wonder and ask voraciously,

140.text: though she cannot fathom your sacrifice,

142.text: she will hold your estimation of it holy,

147.text:
Did you fight?
Were you fearful or fearsome?

150.text: What colored the walls of your regret?

152.text:
What did you do for women
in the year it was time?

154.text:
This path you made for me,
which bones had to break?

157.text: Did you do enough, and are you OK, momma?

161.text: She will ask the difficult questions.

163.text:
She will not care
about the arc of your brow,

167.text: She will not ask of your mentions.

169.text:
Your daughter, for whom you have
already carried so much, wants to know

172.text:
what you brought, what gift,
what light did you keep from extinction?

175.text: When they came for victims in the night,

177.text:
did you sleep through it
or were you roused?

180.text: What was the cost of staying woke?

181.text:
What, in the year we said time's up,
what did you do with your privilege?

185.text: Did you sup on others' squalor?

186.text:
Did you look away
or directly into the flame?

188.text:
Did you know your skill
or treat it like a liability?

191.text:
Were you fooled by the epithets
of "nasty" or "less than"?

194.text:
Did you teach with an open heart
or a clenched fist?

198.text: Tell her the truth. Make it your life.

200.text: Confirm it. Say, "Daughter, I stood there

202.text:
with the moment
drawn on my face like a dagger,

204.text: and flung it back at itself,

207.text:
Tell her the truth, how you lived
in spite of crooked odds.

211.text:
and always, always
in the company of courage,

213.text:
mostly the days
when you just had yourself.

216.text: Tell her she was born as you were,

218.text:
as your mothers before,
and the sisters beside them,

220.text: in the age of legends, like always.

223.text: Tell her she was born just in time,
